text:
Hi everyone. It's Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. Let's talk about the word "though."

Though. This word has two different uses, so we're 
going to make sure you understand the difference.

First, we can use it like "although" or 
"even though." It expresses a contrast.

We use "though" to introduce a 
surprising or contrasting idea.

We form an adverb clause with "though," 
which means "though" functions as a

subordinating conjunction. It joins 
ideas together. Here's an example.

Though I know too much sugar isn't 
good, I admit I have a sweet tooth.

I can also flip this around and 
say, "I admit I have a sweet tooth,
though I know too much sugar isn't good."
The adverb clause is part of a complex sentence.

There's an independent clause 
and a dependent clause.

In this example, I can also use 
"although" and "even though."

The words do the same job. Although I know too 
much sugar isn't good... Even though I know

too much sugar isn't good... All three words, 
all three conjunctions express a contrast.

It's useful to know different 
structures that allow you to express

basically the same ideas. Can you 
rewrite these two sentences using "but"?

Here's how I'd rewrite them. I 
really love chocolate and pastries,
but I try to limit how much sugar I eat.

Cake isn't healthy, but it's okay to treat 
yourself to a slice every now and then.

How would you complete this sentence? 
Though I had to stay home all week...
You can tell me your idea in the comments.

Now here's the second use of "though." We can use 
it like "however" -- another word of contrast.

In this use, we place "though" at 
the end of a sentence. Take a look.

I enjoyed the dinner a lot. I didn't eat 
much, though. I had eaten a big lunch.

I see my neighbors almost every day, I 
haven't seen Mr. Riley in a few days, though.
Quick quiz. Listen to these two statements.

One. I'd love to watch that movie. I'm a little 
tired, though. Maybe tomorrow night? Two.

Movies are entertaining. However, we must not 
forget the value of reading quality fiction.

Now which statement is more 
typical of spoken English?

One. Right? The first statement is what I would 
say. The second statement is what I would write.
Both "though" and "however" express a contrast.

"However" is something that we use more in 
writing, and it sounds a bit more formal,

so think of "though" as a contrast 
word used in spoken English.

How would you complete this statement? They say 
you should exercise a few times a week...though.
Again you can tell me your idea in the comments.

That's all for now. As always, thanks for 
watching and happy studies! I'd like to say a
